author: By Ken Belson
title: Winless Falcons Fire Coach and General Manager
description: Atlanta is the second team to clean house to try to salvage its season.
content: The Atlanta Falcons, winless through five games this season, have fired their head coach, Dan Quinn, and general manager, Thomas Dimitroff, becoming the second team to reassess its fading prospects for the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: What It’s Like to Watch Hurricanes Batter Your Hometown — Over and Over
description: Epic storms have battered Lake Charles, La., my hometown. Each hurricane season, a part of my chest tightens and I brace for what may be next.
content: Storm after storm after storm seems to head right for the small Louisiana town where I was born. In late August, Hurricane Laura hit Lake Charles hard. Over the weekend, many homes were again flooded after Hurricane Delta rolled through. Years ago, a powerful hurricane pushed my family into Lake Charles, and later, another pushed us out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Don DeLillo, an Old Hand at Paranoia and Dread, Meets Us Where We Are
description: In “The Silence,” two wealthy couples watch the Super Bowl together as power grids mysteriously go down all over the world.
content: One day in the aughts, a colleague at The New York Times Book Review, D.J.R. Bruckner, known to all as Don, wandered over to my cubicle. Don was very tall, slightly stooped, had enormous hands and feet, and had been on Nixon’s enemies list. He was visibly shaking. He pointed to his right. “If I have to read one more 2,000-word review of a John Updike book,” he said, “I am going to throw myself out that window.” I’ve omitted his obscenities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas St. Fleur
title: Who Would Win in a Dinosaur Battle Royale?
description: A cheat sheet for parents of dino-obsessed kids.
content: For a recent series on the state of play, we asked Nicholas St. Fleur, a science writer and dinosaur lover, for a guide to playing with dino-obsessed kids. As an added bonus, he gave us this handy cheat sheet to just how all our children’s toys stack up against each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Mitch McConnell’s Mission of Misery
description: Why Senate Republicans won’t help Americans in need.
content: I keep seeing news reports saying that the Trump administration is “pivoting” on economic stimulus. But Donald Trump has been reversing positions so frequently that it looks less like a series of pivots than like a tailspin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: You Can’t Escape Uber’s Lobbying
description: Just being a customer now makes people a target for inescapable corporate advocacy.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Senator Gary Peters shares the ‘gut-wrenching’ story of his ex-wife’s lifesaving abortion.
description: Senator Gary Peters revealed his ex-wife’s “gut-wrenching” decision to have a lifesaving abortion, becoming one of the first members of Congress to open up about the procedure.
content: Senator Gary Peters of Michigan, a Democrat facing a competitive race for re-election, on Monday became one of only a handful of members of Congress to share a personal experience with abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 12, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 12, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 12, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: As N.Y.C. Jails Become More Violent, Solitary Confinement Persists
description: Even as Mayor Bill de Blasio has emptied out the city’s jails, the number of people who are placed in punitive segregation each year has remained about the same.
content: The number of people held in New York City jails has dropped steadily under Mayor Bill de Blasio, and it continued to fall this year as the city emptied out its jails to curb the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Stephanie Saul
title: Georgians Flock for Early Voting, Facing Glitches and Long Lines
description: Determined and energized voters in the battleground state waited in some places for hours to cast their ballots on the first day of early, in-person balloting.
content: Fired-up voters across Georgia descended on polling sites in record-breaking numbers on Monday, the first day of early, in-person balloting, as state and local officials reported glitches with the state’s new and troubled voting system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Coronavirus, QAnon, Trump: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway Will Be a While. These Venues Say They’re Ready Now.
description: Directors of large flexible spaces like the Park Avenue Armory are lobbying for permission to put on indoor shows for socially distanced audiences.
content: The Park Avenue Armory’s vast drill hall has nearly 40,000 square feet of unobstructed open area. The Shed’s central performance space has a 115-foot-high ceiling. St. Ann’s Warehouse has 10 big double doors and a new air ionization system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Biden says Barrett’s faith should be off-limits.
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Monday that Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s Catholic faith should not be a factor in her Supreme Court confirmation hearing.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Monday that Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s Catholic faith should not be a factor in her Supreme Court confirmation hearing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: First, a Vaccine Approval. Then ‘Chaos and Confusion.’
description: Come spring, Americans may have their choice of several so-so coronavirus vaccines — with no way of knowing which one is best.
content: The United States may be within months of a profound turning point in the country’s fight against the coronavirus: the first working vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Rooted in Faith, Amy Coney Barrett Represents a New Conservatism
description: As Judge Barrett’s confirmation hearings are set to begin Monday, her background and résumé are a stark departure from those of more traditional nominees to the Supreme Court.
content: On a winter afternoon in 2018, Judge Amy Coney Barrett rose to speak in Notre Dame Law School’s wood-paneled courtroom and thanked the people gathered there for joining her for her official investiture as a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Wife of Pennsylvania’s Lieutenant Governor Is Target of Racial Slur
description: Gisele Barreto Fetterman, the wife of Lt. Gov. John Fetterman, said a woman taunted her at a grocery store. Ms. Fetterman shared video of the confrontation on Twitter.
content: Gisele Barreto Fetterman, the wife of Pennsylvania’s lieutenant governor, went to the grocery store on Sunday to pick up some golden kiwis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: 21 Savage Hits No. 1, With an Assist From Morgan Freeman
description: The rapper’s “Savage Mode II,” with the producer Metro Boomin, features Hollywood-style narration from Freeman’s voice-of-God baritone.
content: To land a No. 1 album, the music industry has a few tried-and-true tricks, like catchy radio singles and a meme-ready YouTube video. The latest chart-topping rap album, however, upped the ante with a Hollywood-style trailer narrated by no less of a pitchman than the actor Morgan Freeman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Jennifer Doudna, New Nobel Laureate, on Science and Covid
description: Monday: A conversation with the U.C. Berkeley professor who shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry. Also: A call for first-time voters.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Aaron Pedersen Is a Different Kind of Archetypal Leading Man
description: The star of the Australian police drama “Mystery Road” harks back to the rugged icons of old westerns. He is also Aboriginal, which makes the role more complicated — and rare.
content: Hat, boots, holster. Furrowed brow and taciturn demeanor. The grizzled, bearded detective Jay Swan may hail from Down Under and travel in an S.U.V. instead of a horse, but he is an immediately recognizable archetype — straight out of a Hollywood western.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley, Luis Ferré-Sadurní, Dana Rubinstein and Joseph Goldstein
title: How a Feud Between Cuomo and de Blasio Led to a Chaotic Virus Crackdown
description: The mayor pushed out a plan, only to have the governor override him, causing unnecessary confusion for thousands of business owners and school parents.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had barely finished a fairly routine coronavirus briefing earlier this month when he got word that the New York City mayor, Bill de Blasio, had just blindsided him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Chicken From Your Oven (and Eleven Madison Park)
description: The restaurant has a new dinner kit, which includes a ready-to-roast bird, sides, dessert and breakfast granola.
content: A chicken roasted in your oven with the chef Daniel Humm looking over your shoulder is what Eleven Madison Park is offering for the first time. Its dinner kit, serving two to four, consists of a ready-to-cook Green Circle chicken (raised on restaurant scraps and stuffed with brioche, foie gras and black truffles), with sides like potato gratin and brown butter squash with seaweed, plus a dessert and granola for the morning. The chicken recipe comes from Mr. Humm’s family. The kit, to order 48 hours in advance, is $275 and will also provide 10 meals for the needy through Rethink, a charity which Mr. Humm helped found. Pickup is available in several points in the tristate region, including the restaurant; at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn; in Montclair, N.J.; Greenwich, Conn.; and Bedford and East Hampton, N.Y. Dinners can be reserved this week and are available for pickup starting Oct. 22.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: U.S. Auction Theorists Win the 2020 Nobel in Economics
description: Paul Milgrom and Robert Wilson were honored for work that has pushed auctions into new and useful territory.
content: Two American economists, Paul R. Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson, were awarded the Nobel in economic science on Monday for improvements to auction theory and inventions of new auction formats — innovations that have had huge practical applications when it comes to allocating scarce resources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: Spirit Halloween Rises from the Dead. Again. And Again.
description: The retailer inspires songs and memes with its near-guaranteed seasonal reappearance each fall. But can it survive this year?
content: Spirit Halloween is once again open for business. The store known for selling costumes and spooky fall décor at temporary pop-up locations across the United States is making bullish moves in a brutal year for retail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Irregular Menstrual Cycles Tied to Shorter Lifespans
description: Compared with women with regular cycles of 26 to 31 days, those with irregular or longer cycles were at higher risk for premature death.
content: Irregular menstrual cycles may be associated with an early death, a new study suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: In Emptier Subways, Violent Crime Is Rising
description: Reports of homicides, rapes and burglaries are posing another challenge to regaining the confidence of passengers during the pandemic.
content: It began in the early days of the pandemic in March, when someone lit a fire inside a subway car that killed the train operator and injured 16 others. In the following months, nearly 500 subway car windows were smashed on the No. 7 line. In August, a man tackled and tried to sexually assault a young woman at a station on the Upper East Side. And in September, a train derailed after a man threw metal clamps that he had stolen onto the tracks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: With Polling Sites Lacking Workers, a New Generation Steps Up
description: Older volunteers are reluctant to work during the pandemic. High school students, who are increasingly politically engaged and have more time, are taking their place.
content: WASHINGTON — During the Wisconsin primary in April, Jacob Major, a high school student, noticed how the line for one of Milwaukee’s five polling locations dragged on for blocks. At the beginning of the pandemic, the city did not have enough volunteers and officials to staff its 180 polling sites, leading it to shutter 175 of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Cowboys Lose Prescott, Beat Giants
description: Dak Prescott’s gruesome ankle injury potentially sidelines him for the rest of the year, as the Dallas Cowboys rallied late to keep the Giants winless through five games.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — Dallas quarterback Dak Prescott sustained a gruesome ankle injury not long after his first career touchdown catch before backup Andy Dalton led a drive to a field goal on the final play, and the Cowboys beat the winless Giants, 37-34, on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: 41 WNET Employees Call for Resignation of C.E.O. Neal Shapiro
description: A monthslong dispute centers on the New York public broadcaster’s planned changes to its diversity council and its leader’s statement on racism.
content: More than three dozen employees at the WNET Group, the parent company of New York’s public television stations, have called for the resignation of the longtime chief executive, Neal Shapiro, saying he had not done enough to improve working conditions for employees, especially those of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: The Crowded, Competitive World of Anti-Trump G.O.P. Groups
description: The Lincoln Project; Republican Voters Against Trump; 43 Alumni for Joe Biden. These groups and others have similar missions but engage in little coordination or sharing of resources.
content: WASHINGTON — Last month, Greg Schott, a lifelong Republican disgusted by President Trump, decided it was time to speak out in a meaningful way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Roberta McCain, the Senator’s Mother and His Beacon, Dies at 108
description: John McCain credited to her his will to survive as a prisoner of war. She later campaigned for him in his 2008 bid for the presidency.
content: Roberta McCain, whose son, Senator John McCain of Arizona, said she had inspired his will to survive as a prisoner of war in Vietnam — and who at 96 campaigned spiritedly in his losing bid for the presidency against Barack Obama in 2008 — died on Monday at her home in Washington. She was 108.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Knife for All That Sourdough
description: The chef Nancy Silverton has designed a sleek limited-edition bread knife for Made In.
content: Made In, the company that sells high-quality cookware and tableware directly to consumers, has a bread knife designed by Nancy Silverton, the California chef and restaurateur known for her baking. It’s serrated with an eight-inch blade and a comfortable bonelike handle made from a composite material attached with brass rivets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lesley M. M. Blume and Anastasiya Osipova
title: Long After the Bomb, Its Story Finds a New Audience
description: “Hiroshima,” one of the first accounts of the devastation in Japan, was read nearly everywhere in the world except Russia. Nearly 75 years later, that is changing.
content: On Aug. 31, 1946, when The New Yorker published John Hersey’s “Hiroshima,” the 30,000-word article’s impact was instantaneous and global.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Losing Two Roommates and Going Out on Her Own
description: Three roommates in a one-bedroom apartment was fine before the pandemic struck, but after? She was ready for a studio.
content: Katherine Dunleavy’s apartment goals for 2020 were modest: After a year and a half of living in a windowless room in a financial district one-bedroom with two roommates, she hoped to upgrade to a room with a window.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: A Dose of Optimism, as the Pandemic Rages On
description: The months ahead will be difficult. But the medical cavalry is coming, and the rest of us know what we need to do.
content: On March 16, back when White House news conferences were still deemed safe to attend, President Trump stood before reporters and announced that drastic nationwide restrictions — in schools, work places, our social lives — were needed to halt the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Trump Funnels Record Subsidies to Farmers Ahead of Election Day
description: Despite an extraordinary government bailout, America’s agriculture sector remains under severe economic pressure.
content: WASHINGTON — For the American farmers President Trump counts on for support, the government money is flowing faster than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth
title: Microsoft Takes Down a Risk to the Election, and Finds the U.S. Doing the Same
description: Fearing Russian ransomware attacks on the election, the company and U.S. Cyber Command mounted similar pre-emptive strikes. It is not clear how long they may work.
content: Microsoft and a team of companies and law enforcement groups have disabled — at least temporarily — one of the world’s largest hacking operations, an effort run by Russian-speaking cybercriminals that officials feared could disrupt the presidential election in three weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Barrett’s Record: A Conservative Who Would Push the Supreme Court to the Right
description: As an appeals court judge, Judge Barrett has issued opinions that have reflected those of her mentor, Justice Antonin Scalia, but with few of his occasional liberal rulings.
content: WASHINGTON — Judge Amy Coney Barrett, President Trump’s pick for the Supreme Court, has compiled an almost uniformly conservative voting record in cases touching on abortion, gun rights, discrimination and immigration. If she is confirmed, she would move the court slightly but firmly to the right, making compromise less likely and putting at risk the right to abortion established in Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: No Home, No Wi-Fi: Pandemic Adds to Strain on Poor College Students
description: Some low-income students have dropped out, and there are growing concerns about hunger and homelessness.
content: Michelle Macario was struggling to follow online classes through the tiny screen of her smartphone. She had no laptop and no Wi-Fi at home, and the library where she normally studied at her community college in Los Angeles was closed. So two weeks into the coronavirus shutdown in the spring, she dropped all of her courses to avoid failing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Walter Ashcraft, College Football Star and a Coach, Dies at 91
description: He was drafted by the Redskins, but an injury prevented him from playing in the N.F.L. He devoted himself to coaching and hospitality work. He died of Covid-19.
content: Walter Ashcraft Jr., 6-foot-7 and 250 pounds by his early 20s, drew on his physique to excel in the Southern California sports world of the mid-20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Republicans’ Galling Bad Faith About the Supreme Court
description: It’s way too late for the right to pretend to care about civic norms.
content: Four years ago, when many Republicans believed that Hillary Clinton was about to be elected president, conservatives plotted to stop her from reshaping the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The Race for a Super-Antibody Against the Coronavirus
description: A network of scientists is chasing the pandemic’s holy grail: an antibody that protects against not just the virus, but also related pathogens that may threaten humans.
content: Even as vaccines are hailed as our best hope against the coronavirus, dozens of scientific groups are working on an alternate defense: monoclonal antibodies. These therapies shot to prominence just this month after President Trump got an infusion of an antibody cocktail made by Regeneron and credited it for his apparent recovery, even calling it a “cure.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Israel Accepts Ethiopians of Jewish Descent, but Fewer Than Promised
description: Israel has been slow to admit Ethiopians whose ancestors converted to Christianity, not seeing them as fully Jewish even if they practice Judaism.
content: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government on Monday approved an airlift of 2,000 Ethiopians of Jewish descent to Israel in the coming months, prompting angry reactions from Ethiopian Israeli activists who insist that about 8,000 should be resettled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Republicans in Disarray
description: For a party that tends to put up a unified front, things are starting to look a little shaky.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: Why Scientists Made Venus Flytraps That Glow
description: By splicing a special gene into the carnivorous plants, scientists visualized the chemistry that helps them snap shut on prey.
content: Provoking a Venus flytrap takes a certain amount of finesse. If you brush just one of the trigger hairs inside of its leaves, the plant likely won’t react. But if you trigger it again quickly enough, it will spring into action, swinging its famous mouth shut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Global Talks on Taxing Tech Firms Will Slip Into 2021
description: The negotiations at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development have progressed on several fronts, but a dispute remains between the Trump administration and key allies.
content: WASHINGTON — International negotiators said on Monday that they would not reach agreement this year on how and where to tax technology giants like Google and Facebook, as talks remain hindered by the pandemic and an ongoing dispute between the United States and other wealthy nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Fatima Faizi
title: In Former Taliban Stronghold, Defiant Women Hit the Gym
description: A women’s health club in Kandahar challenges conservative Afghan traditions that vilify exercise for women. Many work out secretly.
content: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Homa Yusafzai felt terrible. Her weight was up, she had diabetes and high blood pressure, and at just 27 she felt lethargic and depressed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New Questions About Leon Black’s Ties to Jeffrey Epstein
description: The billionaire chief of Apollo Global Management had a far deeper relationship than previously known.
content: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Taylor
title: H.B.C.U. Homecomings Are Canceled, but Students and Alumni Will Feast Anyway
description: Brunch, a major part of homecoming at historically Black colleges and universities, is still on for this year, even if it has to be virtual.
content: Matriculation at historically Black colleges and universities is more than late-night study sessions: It’s a balancing act between academics and discovering merriment, and learning how to be. It’s routine to walk the same grassy quadrant as ancestors who believed education was a weapon, while making plans to let off steam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Margaret Nolan, ‘Goldfinger’ Actress, Dies at 76
description: She drew fame at age 20, painted in gold, in the Bond film’s opening credits, then went on to appear in “A Hard Day’s Night,” with the Beatles, and other productions, before turning to art and politics.
content: Margaret Nolan, a stage and screen actress whose gold-painted body was used as a canvas to project the opening credits of the James Bond film “Goldfinger” and who played the character Dink in the movie, died on Oct. 5 at her home in Belsize Park, London. She was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why the Left Is Losing on Abortion
description: The volatile issue is front and center in Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s nomination to the Supreme Court. An abortion rights leader tells us how we got to this point.
content: Most Americans say that abortion should be legal with some restrictions, but President Trump’s nominee for the Supreme Court, Amy Coney Barrett, signed a statement in a 2006 newspaper advertisement opposing “abortion on demand.” Her accession would bolster a conservative majority among the justices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Leonard
title: Charles Koch’s Big Bet on Barrett
description: For almost 50 years, the multibillionaire has been pushing for a court unfriendly to regulation of the market. He may be on the brink of victory.
content: Charles Koch has activated his political network to support Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s nomination, and to tip the scales on her nomination battle in the U.S. Senate. While much of the commentary about Judge Barrett’s nomination has focused on the real prospect that Roe v. Wade may be undermined or overturned, Mr. Koch has other concerns. Judge Barrett’s nomination is the latest battleground in his decades-long war to reshape American society in a way that ensures that corporations can operate with untrammeled freedom. It may be a pivotal one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Facebook Bans Content About Holocaust Denial From Its Site
description: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, once cited Holocaust denial as something he would allow on the social network for free speech reasons.
content: In 2018, Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, famously cited Holocaust deniers in a fumbled attempt to make a point about free speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Fargo’ Season 4, Episode 4 Recap: Something Rotten
description: Sometimes when a bag of money smells a little suspect, that’s because it is.
content: Underneath the expected mélange of funny names, regional dialect, Coen references and knottily orchestrated mayhem, this season of “Fargo” has sought to make a big statement about America. That was clear from the opening sequences in Kansas City, which depict the succession of immigrant groups who turned to criminality as a path to legitimacy. Becoming a true American, the show suggests, involves surviving a cycle of discrimination and conquest — and no single group of people is going to hand power to another willingly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Bangladesh to Allow Death Penalty for Rape Convictions
description: Ministers approved an amendment that would permit capital punishment for the crime after a series of assaults led to widespread calls to tackle what many say is a systemic problem.
content: The government of Bangladesh has approved measures to allow for the death penalty for rape, after several high-profile sexual assault cases set off widespread protests in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: The Three-Child American Family, Under Siege
description: Car-seat woes, the cost of day care and now the pandemic. Yet a rising number of parents still want more than two children.
content: There has been much fretting in recent years about falling fertility in the United States — most recently because of a new economics paper showing that stricter car seat laws may cause people to have fewer children.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: C.E.O.s Rediscover Family Mealtime, a Ritual That’s Become a ‘Priority Again’
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 12, 2020.
content: “Cooking with kids and the family — that’s the new downtime. That replaces the airplane nap at takeoff.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: What the near future may hold
content: We begin this week peering into a crystal ball. Two New York Times science reporters, Carl Zimmer and Donald G. McNeil Jr., looked ahead to the next year of the pandemic and wrote about how the next few months may unspool — both for better and for worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The Precedent, and Perils, of Court Packing
description: As the Senate begins hearings for Judge Amy Coney Barrett, some liberals say expanding the size of the Supreme Court would be a fitting response to recent Republican moves in the confirmation wars.
content: WASHINGTON — There have been nine seats on the Supreme Court for a long time. Could that change?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Who Is That Masked Man?
description: The president is not the only one adjusting to a new political reality.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, three weeks until the election. I know there are people who claim to be undecided when pollsters call, but I think they’re just being contrarian. Do you believe there are people who are still making up their minds?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Judith Levitt
title: Amy Coney Barrett, Vaccines, Election Polls: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Nigerians Demand End to Police Squad Known for Brutalizing the Young
description: The government said it would bow to the demands of Nigerians protesting police abuses, but skeptical protesters vowed to keep the pressure on.
content: LAGOS, Nigeria — With protests breaking out across Nigeria and in expatriate Nigerian communities around the world, the country’s president vowed to a skeptical public on Monday that he would crack down on rogue police officers accused of brutalizing citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: For Both Swiatek and Nadal, Staying ‘In the Moment’ at French Open Was Key
description: Swiatek sought help specifically to tune away outside pressures. Nadal has spent a long career being realistic about problems. They each rolled through the French Open without losing a set.
content: A French Open women’s champion emerging. A French Open men’s champion enduring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Mac and Cheese Goes Nationwide
description: Murray’s Cheese now ships its rich casserole across the country. It’s reopening a cafe in Greenwich Village, too.
content: When I tested the recipe for Murray’s Cheese’s macaroni and cheese for the City Harvest cookbook several years ago, my family said it was the best mac and cheese they had ever eaten. Murray’s has been selling it in New York to take home, and now they have started shipping it nationwide. It comes frozen, ready to reheat — 32 ounces of gooey richness that might be enough for four but more likely two. Or even just one. You can dig in while watching one of Murray’s new virtual cheese classes, including several covering fall, Halloween and the holidays. Murray’s Mac & Cheese, a cafe, is also reopening this week with an expanded menu of mac and cheese, grilled cheese, salads, wine, beer and cider, with outdoor seating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: Votes and Vitality in Mind, Trump Addresses Rally in Florida
description: “I feel so powerful,” the president said in a 65-minute speech. His voice sounded hoarse, but he claimed he was fully recovered and therefore immune to the coronavirus.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump, eager to prove he is healthy and energetic despite his recent hospitalization for Covid-19, returned to the campaign trail on Monday night in Florida, speaking for just over an hour in a state that his advisers think he must win in November, but where voters were overwhelmingly repelled by his performance in the first general election debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Wine Dispenser for Your Counter
description: The Boxxle, which holds four bottles of wine or the wine bladder from a box wine, conveniently dispenses wine whenever you need it.
content: The Boxxle provides a more elegant option than a cardboard box for dispensing wine in bulk, much like decanting that grocery store container of milk into a pitcher. The sleek unit, sheathed in stainless steel, comes empty, with plastic bags that you can insert and fill with three liters (four standard bottles) of wine. As with wine in a box, the bag collapses as the liquid is drawn off, keeping the oxygen out and maintaining the quality of the wine for weeks, even months. (You can even transfer the bag from boxed wine directly into the Boxxle.) The tap is conveniently placed at the top, so there’s room for a glass underneath when the appliance sits on a counter. It’s easy to set up. Refrigerating it requires more than 12 inches of clearance, but a version holding five liters with a chilling feature is in the works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Miller
title: Their Bosses Asked Them to Lead Diversity Reviews. Guess Why.
description: When corporations try to belatedly address issues of diversity, equity and inclusion, they often drop the responsibility on their few Black employees.
content: Last June, Deana Jean received a strange request on LinkedIn: A software company wanted her to lead a diversity, equity and inclusion program for their executive suite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Democrats in Trump Country: They’re Not Shy Anymore About Liking Biden
description: As the campaign enters the final stretch, some Democrats in Trump country are less hesitant than before to express their preference. The surge in enthusiasm reflects an urgency for Democrats desperate to oust the president.
content: LATROBE, Pa. — When Vicki Simon passes the rare fellow Biden supporter in her small town in western Pennsylvania, she quietly flashes a covert hand signal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Lovecraft Country’ and the Billboard Music Awards
description: HBO’s series wraps up its first season; Doja Cat, Bad Bunny and others perform live; and the filmed version of David Byrne’s “American Utopia” debuts.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV Oct. 12-18. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: “ကျုပ်တို့က ကျည်ပြီးတယ်” ကလေးစစ်သားတို့ကြီးပြင်းလာချိန်မှာ စစ်၏အမွေက သက်ဆိုးရှည်ဆဲပင်
description: ဘုရားသခင်၏တပ်တော်(God’s Army) အမွှာခေါင်းဆောင်နှစ်ဦးမှာ ပဉ္စလက်စွမ်းပကားတို့ရှိသည်ဟု တချိန်က ထင်မြင်ထားသည်။ ယခုအခါ သူတို့ လူလားမြောက်နေပြီ၊ တိုင်းပြည်စွန့်ခွာရမှု၊ အရက်နှင့် ပူဆွေး စိတ်ဒဏ်ရာတို့ကို သူတိုရင်ဆိုင်နေရဆဲ။
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: The French prime minister warns that local lockdowns may be imposed as cases surge.
description: France is weighing the possibility of local lockdowns as the country battles a second wave of the coronavirus epidemic, Prime Minister Jean Castex said Monday.
content: France is weighing the possibility of local lockdowns as the country battles a second wave of the coronavirus epidemic, Prime Minister Jean Castex said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Planned Parenthood’s Plan for Amy Coney Barrett
description: As one woman, Supreme Court nominee Amy Coney Barrett, stands ready to derail reproductive rights, another, Planned Parenthood President Alexis McGill Johnson, stands ready to defend them.
content: Roe v. Wade is under threat. As Republican senators scramble to fill Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s seat with a conservative justice who would tilt the court six to three, the nation’s largest abortion and reproductive rights provider has its own power playbook. In this episode of Sway, Kara Swisher speaks to Planned Parenthood’s president and C.E.O., Alexis McGill Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Amy Chang Chien
title: BTS Honored Korean War Sacrifices. Some in China Detected an Insult.
description: Samsung and Fila distanced themselves from the K-pop band, becoming the latest example of multinational companies deferring to Chinese patriotic sentiment.
content: It seemed an innocuous remark from a wildly popular boy band known more for its open-armed inclusiveness than for any overt provocation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Trump still owns the news cycle. But power is rapidly shifting to voters and the courts in battleground states.
description: Monday brought sound (the clamorous kickoff of Amy Coney Barrett’s Supreme Court confirmation hearings) and fury (President’s Trump’s defiant, four-rallies-in-a-row return to the campaign trail), but the quiet footfalls of voters in Georgia resounded just as loudly.
content: Monday brought sound (the clamorous kickoff of Amy Coney Barrett’s Supreme Court confirmation hearings) and fury (President’s Trump’s defiant, four-rallies-in-a-row return to the campaign trail), but the quiet footfalls of voters in Georgia resounded just as loudly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melanie Abrams
title: Karen Elson on Body Shaming, Nudity and Speaking Up for Herself
description: In a new autobiography, the model pulls back the curtain on her career.
content: Models are generally thought of as people who are seen and not heard, but every once in a while one of them breaks the sound barrier. Such is the case with Karen Elson, the red-haired mannequin who dominated fashion imagery at the turn of the millennium, and who has just written a no-holds-barred autobiography.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: After a Year in the Ice, the Biggest-Ever Arctic Science Mission Ends
description: The research ship Polarstern docked in Germany after nearly 13 months studying the rapidly changing region.
content: After a year spent drifting across the top of the world, frozen in sea ice, a German research ship returned home on Monday, ending the largest Arctic science expedition in history, one aimed at better understanding a region that is rapidly changing as the world warms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Protesters in Portland Topple Statues of Lincoln and Roosevelt
description: The demonstrations highlighted a mass execution overseen by Abraham Lincoln and also targeted Theodore Roosevelt.
content: SEATTLE — Protesters in Portland, Ore., swept through the city on Sunday night, toppling statues of Abraham Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt and damaging the entrance to the Oregon Historical Society in a demonstration against colonization and the treatment of Native Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: As Trump Flouts Safety Protocols, News Outlets Balk at Close Coverage
description: Newspapers and networks are wary of exposing their staff members to the president and his aides, saying they do not have assurance that basic precautions will be taken to protect reporters’ health.
content: Major news organizations have become increasingly wary of sending journalists to travel with President Trump to White House events and campaign rallies, as the president and his aides continue to shun safety protocols after an outbreak of the coronavirus within their ranks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: The parties offer divergent portraits of Barrett as the Senate opens hearings.
description: Democrats and Republicans offered divergent portraits of Judge Amy Coney Barrett as the Senate opened her Supreme Court confirmation hearings.
content: As the Senate dives into the confirmation hearings for Judge Amy Coney Barrett, Republicans and Democrats are offering two starkly divergent portraits of a nominee who would tilt the court decisively to the right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Story of Barbuto
description: Jonathan Waxman shares recipes from his vibrant, casual West Village restaurant in a new cookbook.
content: Since 2004, Jonathan Waxman — the California chef credited for bringing the fresh, sunny cooking of his home state to New York decades ago — has been at the helm of Barbuto, a casual, welcoming and highly regarded West Village restaurant. It had to vacate its garagelike premises last year. Then, just a few weeks after opening in a new space nearby, Barbuto was derailed by the pandemic. Mr. Waxman’s new cookbook about the restaurant gives its history, notably explaining why so much of his food relates to Italy. Even his famous roast chicken is slathered with salsa verde. The recipes in this book, including the chicken, are simple affairs, often amounting to a centerpiece protein precisely cooked, then dressed with a salad or vegetable and sauce. His baked hake with leeks is a fine example. Cauliflower soup and cacio e pepe are two recipes worth whipping up on short notice. Pizza-making and pastas are covered in depth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Floyd Cardoz’s Memory Lives On Through Masalas
description: Three spice blends from Burlap & Barrel were created before the chef died of Covid-19 in March.
content: Before he died of Covid-19 in March, the popular Indian chef and restaurateur Floyd Cardoz was working with Burlap & Barrel, a Queens spice company that specializes in sustainable, single-origin products, to create a line of masala blends. Thanks to the continuing participation of Barkha Cardoz, his wife, they are now available. In addition to garam masala — the aromatic, complex and somewhat fruity blend that’s fairly well known, there are also a Goan masala that’s fueled with ginger and packs some heat, and a Kashmiri masala, an earthy, ruddy mix with a hot-yet-sweet chile profile. More Floyd Cardoz blends are also in the works; $1 per jar goes to the charity Cookies for Kids’ Cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: ‘We Were Bulletproof’: As Child Soldiers Grow Up, Legacy of War Lingers
description: Twin leaders of Myanmar’s God’s Army were once thought to have magical powers. Now adults, they are contending with the trauma of exile, alcohol and loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Sheila Kaplan
title: Fauci cautions Trump against holding large rallies, saying it is ‘asking for trouble.’
description: Hours before President Trump campaigns in Florida, Dr. Anthony Fauci cautioned against holding rallies, saying it was ‘asking for trouble.’
content: Hours before President Trump was set to return to the campaign trail in Florida on Monday, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, warned that holding large rallies was “asking for trouble” with cases of the coronavirus surging in many states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: Florida Sees Signals of a Climate-Driven Housing Crisis
description: Home sales in areas most vulnerable to sea-level rise began falling around 2013, researchers found. Now, prices are following a similar downward path.
content: If rising seas cause America’s coastal housing market to dive — or, as many economists warn, when — the beginning might look a little like what’s happening in the tiny town of Bal Harbour, a glittering community on the northernmost tip of Miami Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Senate Judiciary Committee is resuming the hearing after taking a lunch break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Seriously Satirizing 231 Years of Flotus in ‘45 Plays’
description: From a pro-slavery Martha Washington to a blank-screen Melania Trump, the wives and other women of the U.S. presidents get sent up and dressed down.
content: Forget “Six,” the musical that was scheduled to open on the evening Broadway shut down in March. A clutch of variously divorced, beheaded, dead — and now delayed — queens of England is nothing compared to the long parade of American first ladies who have graced the White House since before there was one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jared Whitlock
title: Bringing Perfect Waves to the Masses
description: Wavemakers have proved they can manufacture ideal surfing conditions. But can they scale it?
content: A surfer on a five-foot wave, crouched and grabbing the board’s edge, emerged from behind the curl of the water to onlookers’ cheers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: British Airways Abruptly Replaces Its Chief Executive
description: Alex Cruz, 54, will be replaced by Sean Doyle, who runs Aer Lingus, as the airline industry suffers its “worst crisis.”
content: British Airways has said it will cut 13,000 jobs as the coronavirus pandemic batters the airline industry. On Monday, it announced one more job was going: the chief executive’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Jaime Harrison’s Stunning Haul
description: A Senate challenger in South Carolina breaks a fund-raising record: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: An enormous fund-raising haul in South Carolina, a stimulus stuck in limbo and a president claiming coronavirus immunity. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Catch up on the latest in the saga of stimulus talks.
description: The gap between the Democrats’ proposed $2.2 trillion relief package and the White House’s $1.8 trillion offer may look relatively small, in the grand scheme of things. But an agreement on the aid that many say is needed to keep the economic recovery on track seems remote despite frenzied talks in recent days.
content: The gap between the Democrats’ proposed $2.2 trillion relief package and the White House’s $1.8 trillion offer may look relatively small, in the grand scheme of things. But an agreement on the aid that many say is needed to keep the economic recovery on track seems remote despite frenzied talks in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: The Digital Divide Starts With a Laptop Shortage
description: A surge in worldwide demand by educators for low-cost laptops has created shipment delays and pitted desperate schools against one another. Districts with deep pockets often win out.
content: When the Guilford County Schools in North Carolina spent more than $27 million to buy 66,000 computers and tablets for students over the summer, the district ran into a problem: There was a shortage of cheap laptops, and the devices wouldn’t arrive until late October or November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Two Parties Offer Dueling Views of Barrett as Confirmation Fight Begins
description: On the first day of the election-season confirmation hearings, Democrats portrayed Judge Amy Coney Barrett as a threat to Americans’ health care coverage as Republicans charged anti-Catholic bias.
content: Republicans and Democrats offered sharply divergent arguments on Monday in a Supreme Court confirmation fight whose outcome is likely to steer the court to the right for years, vying to define Judge Amy Coney Barrett and frame the political stakes of President Trump’s rush to install her before he faces voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Lakers’ Winding Path Ends With a Championship
description: The Los Angeles Lakers defeated the Miami Heat in six games to take home the franchise’s 17th championship. It was the fourth title for LeBron James.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — It was not a season. For the Los Angeles Lakers, it was an obstacle course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yanzhong Huang
title: When the U.S. and China Fight, It Is the Environment That Suffers
description: The Trump administration’s moves to decouple the two economies means less leverage over Beijing’s green policies.
content: President Xi Jinping of China recently pledged to the United Nations General Assembly that the country would become carbon neutral by 2060. It was an unexpected announcement from the world’s greatest emitter of carbon dioxide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Qingdao, vaccines, U.S. Supreme Court: Here’s what you need to know.
content: The authorities in Qingdao have begun a five-day campaign to test all of its 9.5 million residents after the seaside city recorded the country’s first locally transmitted coronavirus cases in almost two months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: N.B.A.’s Hollywood Ending Still Leaves Questions
description: There’s a champion (Lakers) and a tally of players with the coronavirus (zero). But as for a date (?), location (??) and salary cap (???) for next season, no one is sure.
content: For the newly crowned N.B.A. champion LeBron James, living and working in the same place for more than three months “played with your mind” and “played with your body.” Phoenix Suns Coach Monty Williams marveled most at an enviable statistic — zero coronavirus-related postponements during the league’s grand sports and social experiment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith E. Whittington
title: Don’t Be So Sure a Justice Barrett Would Overturn Roe
description: She has already been called an extremist on questions of precedent. But in her writing, she has expressed a decidedly mainstream view.
content: As Amy Coney Barrett’s confirmation hearings begin this week in the Senate Judiciary Committee, there is little doubt that her views about judicial precedents will be prominently featured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: Sauce Makers and Scoundrels: Four Hot Romance Novels
description: New releases take you inside a Tang Dynasty palace, behind the scenes at a reality-TV set and into the fields of a 1970s British farm.
content: The start of the school year is always autumn’s great punctuation mark: I tend to think of it as the opening of a pair of brackets, but this year with all the confusion and panic it feels more like an interrobang. We’ll have to scrabble together what scraps of learning we can — just like the scientists, scholars, sauce makers and stroke survivors featured in this month’s romances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Imagining the Trump Presidency That Wasn’t
description: A politically incorrect administration might have succeeded where this one failed.
content: Where would we be now if we had a truly politically incorrect president? Donald Trump is supposed to be politically incorrect, but, for the most part, he isn’t. He’s mainly just a jerk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: Showtime in a Potential Petri Dish
description: The Senate confirmation hearings for Judge Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court are a different kind of pinstripe rodeo — one with hazmat suits.
content: WASHINGTON — There is, traditionally, a predictable rhythm to the start of a “much-awaited hearing” on Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: Tommy Tuberville’s Financial Fumbles
description: Mr. Tuberville, the former football coach and Alabama Senate candidate, is leading Senator Doug Jones in the polls. But his financial record raises questions.
content: Tommy Tuberville, the Republican candidate for Senate in Alabama, is running in large measure on his experience in college football’s Southeastern Conference, known as the S.E.C., where he coached Auburn University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Can Trump cede the spotlight to Judge Barrett’s hearings?
description: As the Supreme Court confirmation hearings begin for Judge Amy Coney Barrett, can President Trump cede the spotlight? And what is Democrats’ strategy?
content: The event that conservatives hoped would reshape the 2020 election is upon us: The Supreme Court confirmation hearings for Judge Amy Coney Barrett began Monday morning and promise to last most of the week. Republicans have regarded her nomination as an opportunity to reinvigorate voters on the right and shift focus away from the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Barrett’s record: a conservative who would push the Supreme Court to the right.
description: Judge Amy Coney Barrett, President Trump’s pick for the Supreme Court, has compiled an almost uniformly conservative voting record in cases touching on abortion, gun rights, discrimination and immigration. If she is confirmed, she would move the court slightly but firmly to the right, making compromise less likely and putting at risk the right to abortion established in Roe v. Wade.
content: Judge Amy Coney Barrett, President Trump’s pick for the Supreme Court, has compiled an almost uniformly conservative voting record in cases touching on abortion, gun rights, discrimination and immigration. If she is confirmed, she would move the court slightly but firmly to the right, making compromise less likely and putting at risk the right to abortion established in Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Is This Still Soccer?
description: In Massachusetts, rules changes brought on by the pandemic — no contact, no tackles, no headers, no throw-ins — are forcing soccer players and coaches to adapt to a very different game.
content: You’re still not allowed to touch the ball with your hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4.5 Million Homes in California
description: A new Craftsman-style house in Newport Beach, a circa 1890 farmhouse in Guerneville and a renovated 1967 house in Marina del Rey.
content: This house is in the Balboa Peninsula Point section of Newport Beach, just across the bay from Corona del Mar. The neighborhood is family-oriented, with annual Fourth of July and Easter events. Within walking distance is West Jetty View Park, a strip of waterfront that includes the Wedge, a spot known for its high waves and for inspiring the surf music legend Dick Dale’s 1963 hit of the same name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Making Sense of Sweden
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: The White House event to celebrate Amy Coney Barrett’s Supreme Court nomination — a gathering that appears to have spread the coronavirus — would have violated the law in Sweden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Disney Reorganization Puts a Sharper Focus on Streaming
description: The move was one of the biggest by Bob Chapek since he became C.E.O. in February.
content: In one of Bob Chapek’s first big moves since taking over as chief executive, the Walt Disney Company announced a realignment of its business divisions on Monday that placed the focus squarely on Disney+ and its other streaming services as the future of the company’s creative efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein, Steve Eder and David Enrich
title: The Billionaire Who Stood by Jeffrey Epstein
description: Leon Black, whose $9 billion fortune could buy the best counsel in the world, paid at least $50 million to Mr. Epstein for advice and services after most others had deserted him.
content: The billionaire financier Leon Black, one of Wall Street’s most powerful executives, was facing questions from clients after Jeffrey Epstein was arrested last year on federal sex trafficking charges. The two men had known each other for decades, and investors of Mr. Black’s investment company, Apollo Global Management, wanted to know how close they had been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Trump Defectors Help Biden Build Leads in Wisconsin and Michigan
description: New polls show Biden is gaining in the Northern battlegrounds among white voters.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. holds a significant lead in the pivotal states of Michigan and Wisconsin, with President Trump so far failing to retain the overwhelming advantage he enjoyed among white voters there in 2016, according to surveys from The New York Times and Siena College on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: E.U. Agrees to Penalize Lukashenko, but Gives Him Time to Back Down
description: Foreign ministers of the bloc, which had imposed sanctions on other Belarus officials, agreed to apply them to the country’s president, pressuring him to call new elections.
content: BRUSSELS — European Union foreign ministers agreed on Monday to impose sanctions on President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, widely seen as having stolen the recent election — but they also appeared to offer him a way out of the penalties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Schwartz
title: Is Everybody Doing … OK? Let’s Ask Social Media
description: Researchers are looking at online behavior to gauge public mental health. The results aren’t pretty.
content: Which was the saddest day of them all?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Cooking Can Help
description: Mondays land heavily sometimes. You may find joy in making something new.
content: Good morning. You doing all right? Mondays land heavily sometimes, especially seven months into this pandemic that stalks the world. It’s been exhausting. We’re working more, or not working enough or at all. We’re staying safe while others aren’t. We’re worrying, staring, thinking, overthinking. We are on, all the time. The weekend comes and maybe we get outside and into the world and maybe that’s a relief, but then it’s over and the circus music blares once more. So I hope you’re all right. I hope you’ll take the time to be all right. That’s work, too, sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: As Trump returns to campaigning, his aides preview a final sprint.
description: Officials with President Trump’s campaign told reporters on Monday that the final stretch of the race would be more frenetic than ever for the president as he tries to make up time he lost battling the coronavirus.
content: Officials with President Trump’s campaign told reporters on Monday that the final stretch of the race would be more frenetic than ever for the president as he tries to make up time he lost battling the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump will hold a rally in Florida and Biden barnstorms in Ohio.
description: Here are the daily schedules of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates for Monday, Oct. 12. All times are Eastern time.
content: Here are the daily schedules of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates for Monday, Oct. 12. All times are Eastern time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: In Terms of Child Mortality, It’s a Good Time for Public Health
description: Despite the crises of 2020, parents can realistically expect that children born today will outlive them. That wasn’t always the case.
content: Rule one of Hollywood screenwriting is, “don’t kill the kid.” Well, actually, rule one is more famously, whatever you do, don’t kill the dog. But if you happen to be a pediatrician who occasionally moonlights as a screenwriter, children come up more frequently; my limited life writing television scripts has involved being hired because someone wants high-stakes pediatric drama, and then being asked to delete story lines about seriously ill children, because sick and dying children are hard to watch. It’s not easy to construct high-stakes pediatric drama without endangering children, though I’ve tried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Mitsuye Tanamachi, World War II Internee, Dies at 97
description: The Japanese-American daughter of a California farmer was confined to a camp in Arizona where she found God and her husband. She died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Handcuffed by a New Rule, Rays Manage to Escape
description: The three-batter-minimum rule gives managers a different set of variables, and the decisions can be just as intriguing.
content: This is the rule that was meant to seem weird in 2020. Before the four-month shutdown, plus-size playoffs, cardboard cutouts, phantom runners, neutral sites and so on, the three-batter-minimum was the radical change for this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Two Huge Questions Loom as 2020 Census Winds Down
description: The most contentious census count in memory is nearing an end with questions remaining about the accuracy of its numbers and how they will be used in congressional reapportionment.
content: WASHINGTON — The Census Bureau, long the gold standard for nonpartisan probity and statistical rigor in the federal government, is rushing toward the close of the most imperiled and politicized population count in memory with two huge issues in dispute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: On Facebook, Misinformation Is More Popular Now Than in 2016
description: People are engaging more on Facebook with content from outlets that publish falsehoods and distortions, even though the social network has tried limiting misinformation, new research found.
content: During the 2016 presidential election, Russian operatives used Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and other social media platforms to spread disinformation to divide the American electorate. Since then, the social media companies have spent billions of dollars and hired tens of thousands of people to help clean up their act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Britain’s New Measures to Control Virus Inflame North-South Tensions
description: Boris Johnson campaigned on a promise to “level up” struggling northern areas, but his three-tier plan threatens to keep them in economically debilitating lockdowns.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Monday ordered pubs, bars and gyms in the high-risk city of Liverpool to be closed, a move that inflamed tensions with local officials and laid bare how the second wave of the coronavirus pandemic is hitting Britain’s north harder than London or the rest of the south.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Taimoor Shah
title: Taliban Test Afghan and U.S. Resolve in Talks by Attacking a City
description: The insurgents have opened an offensive against the capital of Helmand Province even as their negotiators remain at the table in Qatar.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban have opened an offensive on the southern Afghan city of Lashkar Gah, overrunning some of its surrounding security checkpoints and largely cutting it off, even as their negotiators remained at the table for talks with the Afghan government that appear stalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Weber
title: Joe Morgan, Hall of Fame Second Baseman, Is Dead at 77
description: Morgan, who later became a well-known television commentator, was among the smallest great players in the history of the game and among the greatest second basemen.
content: Joe Morgan, the Hall of Fame second baseman who was the National League’s Most Valuable Player for two consecutive seasons and the engine of the Big Red Machine — as the Cincinnati Reds of the 1970s, one of baseball’s most powerful teams, were known — died on Sunday at his home in Danville, Calif. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: Let’s say you want to send an email to a list of people, but you don’t want the recipients to see who else is on the list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Top General Declines to Endorse Trump’s Afghan Withdrawal Timeline
description: The comments from Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, came after the White House tripped over itself on the issue of Afghanistan troop levels in recent days.
content: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top general declined on Sunday to endorse either of the sudden announcements on Afghan troop withdrawals that came out of the White House last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: ‘Everything Is Closed Down.’ The Lack of Youth Sports Is a Crisis.
description: Despite a glut of sports on TV, the lack of youth leagues and teams in the pandemic could cost us for years to come.
content: Tyrone Riley is worried. He is a basketball coach and a father, and he is witnessing firsthand the devastating effects of the coronavirus pandemic on youth sports in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: An Italian Teenager Could Become the First Millennial Saint
description: Carlo Acutis, who died at 15 in 2006 and was an early adopter of the internet, was beatified over the weekend, putting him on the path to sainthood in the Catholic Church.
content: In many ways, Carlo Acutis was a typical teenager. He loved his PlayStation and making videos of his dogs. He favored Nikes and jeans, and he had a cellphone and an email address.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Ingram
title: A Glance at Daily Life Among the Caretakers of Britain’s Small Islands
description: Stationed off the coast of Britain, island wardens manage the preservation of their small speck of land — while coping with extreme weather and limited access to the mainland.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Alex Ingram shares a collection of images from small British islands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Biden Pushes to Flip Ohio With a Populist Pitch to Workers
description: In Toledo, Joe Biden lashed President Trump as an out-of-touch plutocrat who has repeatedly betrayed union workers, while playing up his own Irish Catholic, middle-class background.
content: Almost four years after President Trump cemented his strength among white working-class voters by winning Ohio, Joseph R. Biden Jr. pushed on Monday to put the state back in play for Democrats in November, as he sought to energize the party’s base and court some of those same Americans who powered Mr. Trump’s victories across the industrial Midwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 5 of the N.F.L. Season
description: Dak Prescott’s season is over, Alex Smith came back after nearly two years away, the Ravens demolished Joe Burrow and the Bengals, and the Raiders shocked the Chiefs.
content: Sunday got off to a rocky start when the N.F.L. announced it would delay this week’s game between the Denver Broncos and the New England Patriots because of continuing issues with the coronavirus. The decision led to a cascade of changes in the coming schedule, and is sure to be a frequent topic of conversation as teams adjust on the fly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: Subways Are Less Busy and Less Safe
description: Violent crime has risen in the pandemic, as criminals may be emboldened  if they’re targeting the only person on a  car or platform.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan
title: Regeneron’s C.E.O. says its promising Covid-19 treatment must be rationed.
description: President Trump said over the weekend that the experimental medication he was given to fight his Covid-19 infection was “standard, pretty routine.” It seems likely it will be anything but should it ever reach the market.
content: President Trump said over the weekend that the experimental medication he was given to fight his Covid-19 infection was “standard, pretty routine.” It seems likely it will be anything but should it ever reach the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: How Mike Brosseau Went From Undrafted to October Hero
description: Four years ago, 1,216 other players were picked instead of Brosseau in the major league draft. But his perseverance led to a moment of glory, and an A.L.C.S. berth for the Rays.
content: After he was humbled and before he was heroic, Mike Brosseau was ready. The 2016 major league draft had come and gone, 30 teams passing on him for 40 rounds. Nobody wanted a senior shortstop with pop, plate discipline and a .355 average in the Horizon League. Brosseau packed his bags for pro ball, anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: How Russell Wilson’s Latest Clutch Drive Beat the Vikings
description: A potential league M.V.P., Wilson led the Seahawks on another game-winning drive — the 30th of his career — Sunday night. “He’s as good as you can get,” Seattle Coach Pete Carroll said.
content: The Seattle Seahawks trailed the Minnesota Vikings by 26-21 on Sunday night and were stuck at their 6-yard line. The bad news: There was only 1 minute 57 seconds to go in the game. The good news: Russell Wilson is the team’s quarterback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: When Symptoms of Covid-19 Don’t Go Away
description: Research is underway to assess the pandemic’s long-term effects and find ways to prevent and treat lasting symptoms.
content: Judy Londa, a 55-year-old Brooklynite who had been traveling by subway to teach art in a Manhattan public school earlier this year, developed symptoms of Covid-19 two days before in-person schooling was abruptly canceled mid-March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Cuomo Unveils Statue of Mother Cabrini
description: A year after a dispute between New York City and the state, a memorial to the patron saint of immigrants is dedicated in Manhattan.
content: When the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio announced last year that a new project, She Built NYC, would commission monuments and memorials for undersung female leaders, the Roman Catholic nun who is considered the patron saint of immigrants was not on the shortlist, upsetting her many Italian-American and Catholic fans, especially because in a public poll, she received the most votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: We All Live in Don DeLillo's World. He's Confused by It Too.
description: “Trying to understand can be somewhat self-enlightening, maybe in a self-deceptive way, but that’s helpful.”
content: “Trying to understand can be somewhat self-enlightening, maybe in a self-deceptive way, but that’s helpful.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Early Voting Brings Long Lines in Georgia
description: Hundreds of people lined up early Monday morning in Georgia to vote in the presidential election. Some voters said on Twitter there were 90-minute delays as multiple machines had to be rebooted.
